Award.AwardTitle: Integrating Geoscience and Career Education in High School
Award.AbstractNarration: The Integrating Geoscience and Career Education in High School project is a Track 1, integrative science and career education program working to increase participation, particularly of students from a diverse background (e.g. gender, ethnicity, low-income families, disabilities), at North Carolina State University (NC State) and encourage completion of high school and enrollment in geoscience programs in universities. Collaborating between researchers, teachers/counselors, and parents, the project is a year-round program for rising 9th to 10th grade high school students (n = 40 each year) in Durham County that focuses on development of understanding fundamental geoscience concepts and emphasizes process and application more than facts. Specifically, the project focuses on coastal landscape studies, faults, rocks, and geospatial techniques, and provides a variety of opportunities to learn in the field with hands-on experience and problem-solving approaches. Activities include field trips, laboratory work, visits to geosciences/GIS agencies, career structured groups, parent workshops, a summer program at the NC Outer Banks, and summer research internships. The project incorporates innovative approaches for leveraging community-university collaborations and using trained graduate students as counselors for high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Objectives #1, 3, 4, 5:

  • improve the quality of formal and informal geoscience education at high school;
  • demonstrate the relevance of geosciences by identifying and promoting traditional and non-traditional career opportunities in the field;
  • increase the number of students enrolling in geoscience courses and degree programs at universities;
  • increase the number of students drawn from groups traditionally underrepresented in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) fields who participate in geoscience courses and degree programs in universities.

 

In 2012-2013: Field trip to Outer Banks:. A pretest-and-posttest approach was used to collect data (n=18) from a competency test.  Overall, the results are significant, students improved from total scores of 62 to 87. In 2013-2014, overall, the results are significant, students improved from total scores of 3.82 to 7.43 (t 11= 5.17, df = 11, p <.001).

 

Pretest-and-posttest results about student’s science knowledge of the trip to NC Natural Science shows significant increase after the trip. The mean scores were 3.60 and 6.47 (t 19 = 4.57, df = 19, p <.001)

 

During the summer internship in 2014, post-test shows an average of 75 (ranged from 50 to 90; n=10) out of a total of 100.

 

Objectives #3

 

  • demonstrate the relevance of geosciences by identifying and promoting traditional and non-traditional career opportunities in the field;

At the end of spring, 2013, the students responded to a self-report survey about their knowledge and interest about geoscience and geoscience careers. Significant differences were found between the program students and the control group (X1 = 4.23 vs. X2 = 3.08, t = 5.34, p <.01).

The Career Decision Making Self-Efficacy Scale (CDMSE; Taylor & Betz, 1983) was adopted for the career group evaluation, which includes 25 items.  At the end of spring, 2013, the students participated in a posttest of the same survey, significant differences were found between the two groups (X1 = 2.7 vs.  X2 =1.65, t = 4.91, p <.01). Again, in spring, 2014, the students participated in a posttest of the same survey, significant differences were found between the two groups (X1 = 4.11 vs.  X2 =1.95, t 47= 5.91, p <.001).

 

A second scale: Academic, College, Career Help-Seeking Scale (ACCHSS; Yeh, Ching, & Okubo, 2005) was adopted to assess student’s study. In 2012-2013, the program students and a comparison group participated in the survey. Mean scores for the pretest were 1.72 vs. 1.83 respectively. Posttest mean scores were 3.23 vs. 1.78 respectively. The program students had a significantly higher mean score than the comparison group (t = 5.82, p<.01). In 2013-2014, mean scores for the pretest were 1.66 vs. 1.73 respectively. Posttest mean scores were 3.43 vs. 1.98 respectively. The program students had a significantly higher mean score than the comparison group (t 47= 5.32, p<.001).

 

A satisfaction survey contains 10 items about each of the geoscience and career event/activity. The rating scale is a 5-point scale from 1: very bad to 5 very good.  The results in 2013 show that the students were satisfied with the program, the mean scores range from 4.12 to 4.85 on a 5-point Likert Scale.
